title: EXMARaLDA meets WebAnno
segmentation: Good morning ladies and gentlemen, it's a pleasure to be here.
Thank you very much for the opportunity to present you the idea of a meeting that concerns true.
You might already know it's Exmor RAA tool for building apps.
Corpora of spoken language and weapon or the famous annotation tool and.
Yes, our talk has several parts.
Of course I would like to introduce to you the project context a little bit of the background of the idea.
I will present you the idea for the use case, analyzing discourse in teacher education, and then hand.
I will tell you a lot of interesting details concerning requirements implementation.
We will close up with some experiences and an outlook as expected.
Well, the motivation to tell you something about the funding of a so-called teaching lab for.
Students who want to become teachers in the future is that in Germany you have a vivid discussion about improving the training for future teachers for innovative teaching formats.
For students who yes want to become teachers and sorry.
Now you can characterize this.
The background for this discussion as follows.
First of all, you have the students who dim and practical violence, relevance in education.
They are always ask how to react as a teacher in my own future lessons and they expect modern forms of information and communication.
But on the other hand, they really suffer from time pressure and that.

Does not only mean they have to earn money for studying, but the time for teaching the specialist disciplines will reduce and the time for pedagogy will increase, and that's difficult for that has difficult consequences for teaching at the University.
On the other hand, the future teachers are expected to instruct pupils in linguistic reflection, especially when they are teaching German, for instance, German.
As a second language, which is my specialization, teachers also have to perform a daily dyok, diagnosis, diagnosis of pupils, actions, and comprehension.
That means they also have to observe, do my pupils understand me?
What in which steps do they progress?
What are the difficulties so that is managed by diagnosis of famous term coined by Ingrid Golding in Hamburg and.

Teachers also are expected to provide state of the art teaching in their specialist disciplines and they have to be prepared to participate in advanced training programs when they're all already teachers.
So teaching at the universities have to prepare them for these demands.
Um?
And this is rather difficult, and a linguist you can say my suggestion to contribute to these problems is to deal with analysis of classroom interaction in my lectures.
The advantage is the interaction in classrooms as word structures and you also have a extent extensive research lead to a trip.

On the other hand, if you address specific constellations of teaching discourse such as comprehension process, you have direct relevance for the students they appreciate, appreciate really much those questions, and you can address different dimensions of language use verbal and also multimodal dimensions of communications as we just heard.
In the plan, really.
But analyzing discourse in education is rather complicated.
Becausw you have it in case you work with discourse data, authentic, discuss data and not vineyards, you have to.
You have to consider different conventions of notation spoken discourse.
You have to consider different traditions in analyzing discourse, and these traditions do not only stand from linguistic but also from sociology pedagogy, pedagogic and other disciplines.
So there are no recipes for teaching.
This course analyzes analysis within education, and that's another complication for doing this job.
Yes, so based on the aims of this teaching lab projects, we set up a list of requirements.
First of all, it's important to consider transcripts as a basis for analysis because the decisions on content and on a layout of transcripts.
They are also very consciously made and relevant to the analysis.
So we need to consider that in user interfaces.

An adaptation of course, within the project of the idea to use this as a way of making students analysis more explicit, and we also want to be able to use these well known ways of comparing annotations.

Looking at the software solution, we thought that a web based solution would be a more convenient for teaching scenario, and of course it's important we think to allow others to not only use the outcome of this project, but also to be able to further build upon it and extended while at the same time.
Of course we need something which is reliable and somewhat sustainable.
So that I know is a popular annotation tools.
Web based advanced has lots of nice features and for first most of these requirements but it lacked support for spoken data so there was no representation.
Any spoken features, no media playback, no transcripts.
What we did was to approach the Language Technology Group at the University of Hamburg Ram plus Beaman.

And we have well brought some money, so they were also very interested in developing section extension for Web banner as a plugin for spoken data in cooperation with the Hamburg Center for Language Corpora.

Or will be providing the expertise on spoken data modeling and formats and developing software for spoken language data which we have been doing for several years with this X milder system for spoken corpora.
So that was one part of this project and another one was to develop a suitable training, teaching corpus or classroom discourse.
So the functionality has various features.
Of course it has to parse transcription data and here we made a very conscious choice not to go for the extra little script format, but for reasons of interoperability.
Of course we want you to use the T based ISO standard for transcription of spoken language.
I internally learning web.
I know this is mapped using these.
We Marcus is at the core of webinar and from those various visualizations based on the transcription conventions used are generated and then we now also have playback of several audio video formats.
Now this sounds very easy and it wasn't, and it never is.
When we have spoken data and we approach tools, platforms, formats, infrastructures.
Maybe that were built with written data in mind with some kind of written language bias actually and it always always have the same issues that occur, just simple things like we have speakers.
So we will have metadata which does not apply to the whole transcription document if you like, but only to certain parts so I can speak your contributions.
And this speaker contributions they might overlap.
We do not have a single stream of tokens, which is a very common assumption about language data.
So you can serialize this, but it's still not trivial.
How to do so, and you need time information.
In the end we have parallel structures and simultaneous events.
We also have a lot of messy stuff we hurt also in the previous talk.
Of course none alogical material which is important.
Nonverbal stuff.

Also sometimes background noises or like an audience that will also very important for the transcript, and we also have time based annotations which might not hurt to a token structure if there is such a thing in the transcription.

So, but in the end I could go on very much about how these have this data is very different and very complex and everything, but in the end you have to find some way of like you know some work arounds and some recommended solutions so that you can actually come up with something as beautiful as this new extension.
And here you have for.
Simple, the speaker assignment now visible in the web and new annotation view.
You have a non fanatical non verbal material clearly marked as such.
And you also.
Aptima like media playback.
So this is actual.
The part of a completely new view, a transcript view which feature.

There's video playback and here you can choose if you want to upload your video talking about data protection of course, and if you otherwise you can just link it from some open repository and you also have.
This transcript visualization based on Esmerelda functionality and this is a transcript in score notation, so you can really see the parallel structures in it.
And so this is one way of visualizing transcription data.
And we also have speaker meta data which is also imported with the so TI file.
So in the end as I said, some work around some creative solutions and it does work.
So I would like to give the floor back track listing to say some more words about how it worked.
Yes.
This summer I work with my students with these transcripts of these were authentic classroom interactions compiled to a corpus.
The students could choose which data they want to treat with, and as you can see, they see I hope you see red lines and marked units and that were the units for observation.
The students had to discuss, and this was really one step of progression.
In teaching them how to analyze authentic language, there check data interaction.
They had to.
They had to consider layers.

They had to ask which unit do do I have which has to be the characteristic for this layer to say something about the process is I want to observe and they could also choose sorry checks and just become more and more reflexive in analysis.
So, um.
While working with transcript just to summarize, the students have to look for a unit of description, not.
At all trivial was consideration, the extent and the character of the units and their relation to the processes of comprehensions.
They could observe to within the discourse data, and they had vivid team discussion.
And when you consider the relation from working with transcripts to the annotation process in weapon or the tool which triggers these processes.
Of analysis, look for the unit of description, of course.
Was the annotation unit.
Of course the.
The further descriptions of this unit consider it's the layers that axe heads and text and the team discussion you can say has to do with Inter annotator agreement and so.

So the benefits with this this lecture were the students or I observed an increased interest on behalf of the students in the field of linguistics, especially in data analysis through data driven data driven discussions they observed some or they discovered some starting points for reflection.
The teachers role in classroom interaction so they could project their questions to their future practices of.
Teaching themselves I got more explicit explicit input for the students understanding of concepts stored in the lecture, because I could observe them.
Why working at the computer that was very helpful for me and the students learned to use tools of digital humanities while focusing on the content of my lecture.
So.
OK, so the teaching method can be used in further contexts and I will.
I am sure I will use it again and again just to to to make it more better and.

I can also of course add that since we are using this ection standard, we tried to make this plugging in such a way that it can be easily extended to provide support for further transcription conventions or data coming from other transcription tools, etc, because that's the idea of this standard.
So yes, that's the outlook I guess.
So and there is a demo version available.
Which you can access.
It's just with demo data and of course the plug-in code is available.
And please also if you have not yet and you work with spoken language data, have a look at the CGI standard.
Yeah, thank you very much and glad to answer any questions.
